ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: DATA=SAS-data-set] 
      
Specifies the input SAS data set. If the DATA= option is not specified, PROC COUNTREG 
uses the most recently created SAS data set.

[Syntax: GROUPID=variable]
      
Specifies an identification variable when a panel data model is estimated. The identification 
variable is used as a cross-sectional ID variable.

Does not row-normalize the spatial weights matrix that is specified in the WMAT= option. By default, 
the spatial weights matrix is required to be row-normalized; that is, the spatial weights matrix has 
unit row sum.

[Syntax: WMAT=SAS-data-set]
      
Specifies the input SAS data set that contains spatial weights matrix. The spatial weights matrix 
is often known as the W matrix.

[Syntax: RESTORE=item-store-name]
      
Specifies the source item store for processing. An item-store-name consists of a one- or two-level name, 
as with SAS data sets. As with data sets, an item store is associated by default with the Work library, 
and any item stores that are created in this library are deleted when the SAS session concludes.

[Syntax: OUTEST=SAS-data-set] 
      
Writes the parameter estimates to an output data set.

Writes the covariance matrix for the parameter estimates to the OUTEST= data set. 
This option is valid only if the OUTEST= option is specified.
Suppresses all printed output.

Prints the correlation matrix of the parameter estimates. This option
can also be specified in the MODEL statement.

Prints the covariance matrix of the parameter estimates. This option
can also be specified in the MODEL statement.

Specifies the type of covariance matrix of the parameter estimates. The quasi-maximum 
likelihood estimates are computed with COVEST=QML. The default is COVEST=HESSIAN.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the covariance from the outer product matrix.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the covariance from the Hessian matrix.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the covariance from the outer product and Hessian matrices.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: METHOD=CONGRA | DBLDOG | NMSIMP | NRA | NRRIDG | QN | TR | NONE]
      
Specifies the iterative minimization method to use. The default is METHOD=NRA.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Specifies that no optimization be performed beyond using the ordinary least squares.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: PLOTS<(global-plot-options)> < = plot-request | (plot-requests)>]
      
Requests that the COUNTREG procedure produce statistical graphics via the Output Delivery System, 
provided that ODS GRAPHICS has been enabled. 

You can specify the following global-plot-options: 
COUNTS(value1 <value2…>) 
  supplies the plots PREDPROB and PREDPROFILE with particular values of the response variable. 
ONLY 
  suppresses the default plots. Only the plots that are specifically requested are produced. 
UNPACKPANEL | UNPACK 
  displays each graph separately. (By default, some graphs can appear together in a single panel.)

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Requests that all plots appropriate for the particular analysis be produced.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Syntax: AUTOCORR<(LAGS=n)>                                  Displays the autocorrelation function plots of the parameters. This plot-request is available only for Bayesian analysis.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Displays the TRACE, AUTOCORR, and DENSITY plots. This plot-request is available only for Bayesian analysis.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: displays the posterior distribution, prior distribution, and maximum likelihood estimates.  This plot-request is available only for Bayesian analysis.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Syntax: DENSITY<(FRINGE)>                                 Displays the kernel density plots of the parameters. This plot-request is available only for Bayesian analysis.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: Produces the overall predictive probabilities of the specified count levels. You must also specify COUNTS in global-plot-options.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Produces the predictive probability profiles of specified count levels against model regressors.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip9: Produces the profile likelihood functions of the model parameters.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip10: Displays the trace plots of the parameters. This plot-request is available only for Bayesian analysis.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip11: Droduces the probability profiles of zero-inflation process selection and zero count prediction against model regressors.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: ABSCONV= | ABSTOL=r] 
      
Specifies an absolute function convergence criterion.

[Syntax: ABSFCONV=r<n> | ABSFTOL=r<n>] 
      
Specifies an absolute function difference convergence criterion.

[Syntax: ABSGCONV=r<n> | ABSGTOL=r<n>] 
      
Specifies an absolute gradient convergence criterion. Termination requires the maximum 
absolute gradient element to be small.

[Syntax: ABSXCONV= | ABSXTOL=r<n>] 
      
Specifies the absolute parameter convergence criterion. Termination requires a small 
Euclidean distance between successive parameter vectors.

[Syntax: DAMPSTEP | DS  <=r>] 
      
Specifies that the initial step-size value a⁰ for each line search (used by the QUANEW, 
CONGRA, or NEWRAP technique) cannot be larger than r times the step-size value used in the 
former iteration.

[Syntax: FCONV=r | FTOL=r] 
      
Specifies the relative function convergence criterion.

[Syntax: FCONV2= | FTOL2=r <n>] 
      
Specifies a second function convergence criterion.

[Syntax:FSIZE=r] 
      
Specifies the FSIZE parameter of the relative function and relative gradient termination 
criteria. The default value is r=0.

[Syntax: GCONV=r | GTOL=r] 
      
Specifies the relative gradient convergence criterion.

Specifies the scaling version of the Hessian or crossproduct Jacobian matrix used in NRRIDG, 
TRUREG, LEVMAR, NEWRAP, or DBLDOG optimization.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that no scaling is done.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the Dennis, Gay, and Welsch (1981) scaling update
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies that di is reset in each iteration

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: INHESSIAN<=r>] 
      
Specifies how the initial estimate of the approximate Hessian is defined for the quasi-Newton 
techniques QUANEW and DBLDOG.

[Syntax: INSTEP=r] 
      
Reduces the length of the first trial step during the line search of the first iterations.

[Syntax: LINESEARCH | LIS | SMETHOD | SM=i] 
      
Specifies the line-search method for the CONGRA, QUANEW, and NEWRAP optimization techniques.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls  for cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is similar to one used by  the Harwell subroutine library.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies a line-search method that needs more function calls than gradient calls for quadratic  and cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is implemented as shown in Fletcher  (1987) and can be modified to an exact line search by using the LSPRECISION= option.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for  cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is implemented as shown in Fletcher  (1987) and can be modified to an exact line search by using the LSPRECISION= option.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for  stepwise extrapolation and cubic interpolation
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies a line-search method that is a modified version of LIS=4.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies golden section line search (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear  approximation.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: Specifies bisection line search (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear  approximation.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Specifies Armijo line-search technique (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for  linear approximation.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: LSPRECISION=r | LSP=r | SPRECISION=r | SP=r] 
      
Specifies the degree of accuracy that should be obtained by the line-search algorithms 
LIS=2 and LIS=3. The default LSPRECISION= values are:

  o For TECH=QUANEW UPDATE=DBFGS, BFGS: r = 0.4
  o For TECH=QUANEW UPDATE=DDFP, DFP: r = 0.06 
  o For TECH=CONGRA UPDATE=all r = 0.1
  o For TECH=NEWRAP NO UPDATE: r = 0.9

[Syntax: MAXFUNC=i | MAXFU=i] 
      
Requires the number of function calls to be no larger than i. The default values are:

  o For TECH= NEWRAP, NRRIDG, TRUREG: i=125 
  o For TECH= DBLDOG, QUANEW: i=500 
  o For TECH= CONGRA: i=1000
  o For TECH= NMSIMP: i=3000

[Syntax: MAXITER= | MAXIT=i <n>] 
      
Requires the number of iterations to be no larger than i. The default values are:

  o For TECH= LEVMAR, NEWRAP, NRRIDG, TRUREG: i=50 
  o For TECH= DBLDOG, QUANEW: i=200 
  o For TECH= CONGRA: i=400
  o For TECH= NMSIMP: i=1000

[Syntax: MAXSTEP=r<n>] 
      
Specifies an upper bound for the step length of the line-search algorithms during the 
first n iterations.

[Syntax: MAXTIME=r] 
      
Requires the CPU time to be no larger than r. The default value of the MAXTIME= option 
is the largest double floating-point number on your computer.

[Syntax: MINITER= | MINIT=i] 
      
Specifies the minimum number of iterations. The default value is 0.
[Displays all optional output for optimization.

Displays the optimization history. The PHISTORY option is set automatically if the PALL 
or PRINT option is set.
Display parameter estimates in each iteration.
Displays the initial values and derivatives (if available).
Restricts the amount of default output.

Restricts the amount of default displayed output to a short form of iteration history and 
notes, warnings, and errors.

[Syntax: RESTART= | REST=i] 
      
Specifies that the QUANEW or CONGRA algorithm is restarted with a steepest descent/ascent 
search direction after at most i iterations, i > 0.
Specifies the fileref that contains the information needed for remote monitoring.

[Syntax: TECHNIQUE= | TECH=name | OMETHOD= | OM=name] 
      
Specifies the optimization technique.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Chooses one of four different conjugate-gradient optimization algorithms, which can be more precisely  defined with the UPDATE= option and modified with the LINESEARCH= option.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Performs a version of double-dogleg optimization, which uses the gradient to update an approximation  of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Performs a usually stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming Newton-Raphson  optimization technique. The algorithm combines a line-search algorithm with ridging, and it  can be modified with the LINESEARCH= option.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Performs a usually stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming Newton-Raphson  optimization technique. This algorithm does not perform a line search.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: Chooses one of four different quasi-Newton optimization algorithms that can be more precisely  defined with the UPDATE= option and modified with the LINESEARCH= option.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: Performs a usually very stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming trust-region  optimization technique. The algorithm is implemented similar to Gay (1983) and Moré and Sorensen (1983).
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Does not perform any optimization. This option is similar to METHOD=NONE, but TECH=NONE also  computes and displays residuals and goodness of fit statistics.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies the update method for the quasi-Newton, double-dogleg, or conjugate-gradient 
optimization technique.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Performs the original Broyden, Fletcher, Goldfarb, and Shanno (BFGS) update of the inverse  Hessian matrix.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Performs the dual BFGS update of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian matrix. This is the default  update method.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Performs the dual Davidon, Fletcher, and Powell (DFP) update of the Cholesky factor of the  Hessian matrix.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Performs the original DFP update of the inverse Hessian matrix.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Performs the automatic restart update method of Powell (1977) and Beale (1972).
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Performs a conjugate-descent update of Fletcher (1987).

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: XCONV= | XTOL=r <n>] 
      
Specifies the relative parameter convergence criterion. Termination requires a 
small relative parameter change in subsequent iterations.

[Syntax: XSIZE=r] 
      
Specifies the XSIZE parameter of the relative parameter termination criterion. The 
default value is r=0.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: AGGREGATION=WEIGHTED |NOWEIGHTED
          
Specifies how multiple posterior samples should be aggregated.

By default, AGGREGATION=NOWEIGHTED.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Implements a weighted resampling scheme for the aggregation of multiple posterior chains. You can use  this option when the posterior distribution is characterized by several very distinct posterior modes.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Aggregates multiple posterior chains without any adjustment. You can use this option when the posterior  distribution is characterized by one or few relatively close posterior modes.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: AUTOMCMC<=(automcmc-options)>
          
Specifies an algorithm for the automated initialization of the MCMC sampling algorithm. You can specify 
the following automcmc-options: 

ACCURACY=(accuracy-options)                                    
  customizes the behavior of the AUTOMCMC algorithm when you are searching for an accurate representation 
of the posterior distribution. You can specify the 
following accuracy-options: 
  ATTEMPTS=number 
    specifies the maximum number of attempts that are required in order to obtain accurate samples from 
  the posterior distribution. By default, ATTEMPTS=10. 
  TARGETESS=number 
    requests that the accuracy search be based on the effective sample size (ESS) analysis 
  TARGETSTATS<=(targetstats-option)> 
    requests that the accuracy search be based on the analysis of the posterior mean.    
MAXNMC=number 
  specifies the maximum number of posterior samples that the AUTOMCMC option allows. By default, MAXNMC=700000.
RANDINIT<=(randinit-options)> 
  specifies random starting points for the MCMC algorithm. You can specify the following randinit-options: 
  MULTIPLIER=(value) 
    specifies the radius of the area where the starting points are sampled.
  PROPORTION=(value) 
    specifies the proportion of starting points that are sampled around the maximum likelihood estimate.
STATIONARITY=(stationarity-options) 
customizes the behavior of the AUTOMCMC algorithm when you are trying to sample from the posterior distribution. 
You can specify the following stationarity-options: 
  ATTEMPTS=number 
    specifies the maximum number of attempts that are required in order to obtain stationary samples.
  TOL=value 
    specifies the proportion of parameters whose samples must be stationary. By default, TOL=0.95.

Syntax: DIAGNOSTICS=ALL | NONE | (keyword-list)  
      
Controls which diagnostics are produced. All the following diagnostics are produced by using 
DIAGNOSTICS=ALL. If you do not want any of these diagnostics, specify DIAGNOSTICS=NONE. If you 
want some but not all of the diagnostics, or if you want to change certain settings of these 
diagnostics, specify a subset of the following keywords. You can specify the following values; 
by default, DIAGNOSTICS=NONE.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: The following keywords are available:                                 AUTOCORR <(autocorr-options)> -- computes default autocorrelations at lags 1, 5, 10, and 50 for each variable.   You can choose other lags by using the following autocorrelation-option: LAGS=(numeric-list) AUTOMCMCSUM -- produces a summary table for the AUTOMCMC (automatic MCMC) sampling tool is used.  ESS -- computes the effective sample sizes (Kass et al. (1998)) of the posterior samples of each parameter. GEWEKE <(FRAC1=value FRAC2=value)>    computes the Geweke spectral density diagnostics, where FRAC1 and FRAC2 specify the beginning FRAC1    and end FRAC2 proportion of the Markov chain, respectively. HEIDELBERGER <(SALPHA=value value EPS=value)>    computes the Heidelberger and Welch diagnostic (which consists of a stationarity test and a halfwidth    test) for each variable.   SALPHA= -- specifies the α level (0 < a < 1) for the stationarity test. By default, SALPHA=0.05   HALPHA= -- specifies the α level (0 < a < 1) for the halfwidth test. By default, HALPHA=0.05.   EPS= -- specifies a small positive number ε such that if the halfwidth is less than ε times    the sample mean of the retaining iterates, the halfwidth test is passed. MCSE | MCERROR -- computes the Monte Carlo standard error for each parameter. RAFTERY <(QUANTILE=value ACCURACY=value PROB=value EPS=value QUANTILE=value)>    computes the Raftery and Lewis diagnostics.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: MARGINLIKE<(NSIM=number)> 
          
Requests evaluation of the logarithm of the marginal likelihood. Two estimates are produced: 
the cross-entropy estimate and the harmonic mean. The cross-entropy estimate is based on an 
importance sampling algorithm for which you can specify the number of importance samples in 
the NSIM= suboption. The default is 10,000.

Syntax: MAXTUNE=number
          
Specifies the maximum number of tuning phases. By default, MAXTUNE=24.

Syntax: MINTUNE=number 
          
Specifies the minimum number of tuning phases. By default, MINTUNE=2.

Syntax: NBI=number 
          
Specifies the number of burn-in iterations before the chains are saved. By default, NBI=1000.

Syntax: NMC=number 
          
Specifies the number of iterations after the burn-in for Metropolis sampling scheme. By default, NMC=1000.

Syntax: NTRDS=number | THREADS=number 
          
Specifies the number of threads to be used. The number of threads cannot exceed the number of computer 
cores available. Each core samples the number of iterations that is specified by the NMC= option. By 
default, NTRDS=1.

Syntax: NTU=number 
          
Specifies the number of samples for each tuning phase for Metropolis sampling schemes. By default, NTU=500.

Syntax: OUTPOST=SAS-data-set 
          
Names the SAS data set to contain the posterior samples. Alternatively, you can create the output 
data set by specifying an ODS OUTPUT statement as follows: 

   ods output posteriorsample=<SAS-data-set>;

[Syntax: PROPCOV=CONGRA | DBLDOG | NEWRAP | NMSIMP | NRRIDG | QUANEW | TRUREG 
          
Specifies the method to use in constructing the initial covariance matrix for the Metropolis-Hastings algorithm.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Performs a version of double-dogleg optimization.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Performs a Newton-Raphson optimization that combines a line-search algorithm with ridging.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Performs a Newton-Raphson optimization with ridging.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: SAMPLING=value 
          
Specifies how to sample from the posterior distribution.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Implements a Metropolis sampling scheme on multiple blocks: one block for each model (all the parameters  of the model) plus a block for all the correlation parameters across the models.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: implements a Metropolis sampling scheme on a single block that contains all the parameters of the model.  SAMPLING=MULTIMETROPOLIS is the default option.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Implements a Metropolis sampling scheme on multiple blocks, one for each parameter of the model.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: SEED=number 
          
Specifies an integer seed in the range 1 to 2^31 - 1 for the random number generator in the simulation. 
Specifying a seed enables you to reproduce identical Markov chains for the same specification. If you 
do not specify the SEED= option, or if you specify SEED=0, a random seed is derived from the time of day, 
which is read from the computer’s clock.
Prints the time required for the MCMC sampling.

Syntax: STATISTICS<(global-options)>=ALL | NONE | keyword | (keyword-list) 
          
Controls the number of posterior statistics that are produced. 

You can specify the following global-options:      
  ALPHA=numeric-list
    controls the probabilities of the credible intervals. By default, ALPHA=0.05
  PERCENT=numeric-list
    requests the percentile points of the posterior samples.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Produces equal-tail credible intervals and HPD intervals.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Produces a summary table of the prior distributions that are used in the Bayesian analysis.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Produces the means, standard deviations, and percentile points (25th, 50th, and 75th) of the posterior samples.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: Suppresses printing of all summary statistics.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: THIN=number | THINNING=number 
          
Controls the thinning of the Markov chain.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: BOUNDS bound1 <, bound2 ...> ; 

The BOUNDS statement imposes simple boundary constraints on the parameter estimates. 
BOUNDS statement constraints refer to the parameters estimated by the COUNTREG procedure. 
You can specify any number of BOUNDS statements.

Syntax: BY variables ; 
      
A BY statement can be used with PROC COUNTREG to obtain separate analyses on observations 
in groups defined by the BY variables. When a BY statement appears, the input data set should 
be sorted in order of the BY variables.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Treats missing values (., ._, .A, …, .Z for numeric variables and blanks for character variables) as valid values for the CLASS variable.
Specifies the sort order for the levels of classification variables.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Sorts levels by the order of appearance in the input data set.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Sorts levels by external formatted values, except for numeric variables that have no explicit format.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Sorts levels by descending frequency count; levels that have more observations come earlier in the order. .
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Sorts levels by unformatted value. Ths sort order is machine-dependent.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: PARAM=EFFECT | GLM | REFERENCE 
          
Specifies the parameterization method for the classification variable or variables.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Uses effect coding to create design matrix columns from the CLASS variables.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Uses less-than-full-rank reference cell coding to create design matrix columns from the CLASS variables.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Uses reference cell coding to create design matrix columns from the CLASS variables.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: REF=’level’ | FIRST | LAST] 
          
Specifies the reference level for PARAM=EFFECT, or PARAM=REFERENCE, and their orthogonalizations.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: For an individual (but not a global) variable REF= option, you can specify the level of the variable  to use as the reference level. Replace 'level' with an actual value, enclosed in quotes.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Designates the first-ordered level as reference.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Designates the last-ordered level as reference.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax:  dependent-variable ~ <dispersion-related-regressors></ option>;

The DISPMODEL statement specifies the dispersion-related-regressors that are used to model dispersion. This statement is ignored unless you specify DIST=COMPOISSON in the MODEL statement.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: SELECT=INFO<(selection-options)> | SELECTVAR=INFO<(selection-options)> 
          
Requests that the variable selection method be based on an information criterion.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: FREQ variable ; 
      
The FREQ statement specifies a variable whose values represent the frequency of 
occurrence of each observation. PROC COUNTREG treats each observation as if it 
appears n times, where n is the value of the FREQ variable for the observation. If 
the frequency value is not an integer, it is truncated to an integer; if it is 
less than 1 or missing, the observation is not used in the model fitting. When 
the FREQ statement is not specified, each observation is assigned a frequency of 
1. If you specify more than one FREQ statement, then the first statement is used.

Syntax: INIT initvalue1 [<, initvalue2 ...>] ; 

The INIT statement sets initial values for parameters in the optimization. 

Each initvalue is written as a parameter or parameter list, followed by an optional 
equal sign (=), followed by a number: 

  parameter <=> number 

For continuous regressors, the names of the parameters are the same as the corresponding 
variables. For a regressor that is a CLASS variable, the parameter name combines the 
corresponding CLASS variable name with the variable level. For interaction and nested 
regressors, the parameter names combine the names of each regressor. The names of the 
parameters can be seen in the OUTEST= data set. By default, initial values are determined 
by OLS regression. Initial values can be displayed with the ITPRINT option in the PROC 
statement.

Syntax: MODEL dependent = regressors / options ; 

The MODEL statement specifies the dependent variable and independent regressor variables 
for the regression model. If you specify no regressors, PROC COUNTREG fits a model that 
contains only an intercept. The dependent count variable should take on only nonnegative 
integer values in the input data set. PROC COUNTREG rounds any positive noninteger count 
values to the nearest integer. PROC COUNTREG ignores any observations with a negative count. 

Only one MODEL statement can be specified.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies a type of model to be analyzed. If you specify this option in both the MODEL statement 
and the PROC COUNTREG statement, then only the value in the MODEL statement is used.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies a negative binomial regression model that uses a linear variance function
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies a negative binomial regression model that users a quadratic variance function
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies a zero-inflated negative binomial regression.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: ERRORCOMP=FIXED | RANDOM 
          
Specifies the type of conditional panel model to be analyzed.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies a fixed-effect error component regression model.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies a random-effect error component regression model.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Suppresses the intercept parameter.

[Syntax: OFFSET=variable] 
          
Specifies a variable in the input data set to be used as an offset variable. The offset variable 
appears as a covariate in the model with its parameter restricted to 1.

Syntax: PARAMETER=MU | LAMBDA 
          
Specifies the parameterization for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson model.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Reparameterizes lambda as documented by Guikema and Coffelt (2008).
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Estimates the original Conway-Maxwell-Poisson model (Shmueli et al. 2005).

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: SELECT=INFO<(selection-options)> | SELECTVAR=INFO<(selection-options)>
Syntax: SELECT=PEN<(selection-options)> | SELECTVAR=INFO=<(selection-options)> 
          
Requests that the variable selection method be based on an information criterion.

Prints the correlation matrix of the parameter estimates. It can also be specified in the 
PROC COUNTREG statement.

Prints the covariance matrix of the parameter estimates. It can also be specified in the 
PROC COUNTREG statement.

Prints the objective function and parameter estimates at each iteration. The objective function 
is the negative log-likelihood function. It can also be specified in the PROC COUNTREG statement.
Requests all printing options. It can also be specified in the PROC COUNTREG statement.

[Syntax: ABSCONV= | ABSTOL=r] 
          
Specifies an absolute function convergence criterion. The default value of r is the negative 
square root of the largest double-precision value, which serves only as a protection against 
overflows.

[Syntax: ABSFCONV=r[n] | ABSFTOL=r[n]] 
          
Specifies an absolute function convergence criterion. The default value is r=0. The optional 
integer value n specifies the number of successive iterations for which the criterion must be 
satisfied before the process can be terminated.

[Syntax: ABSGCONV=r[n] | ABSGTOL=r[n]] 
          
Specifies an absolute gradient convergence criterion. The default value is r=1E-5. 
The optional integer value n specifies the number of successive iterations for which 
the criterion must be satisfied before the process can be terminated.

[Syntax: ABSXCONV= | ABSXTOL=r[n]] 
          
Specifies the absolute parameter convergence criterion. The default is r=1E-8 for the 
NMSIMP technique and r=0 otherwise. The optional integer value n specifies the number of 
successive iterations for which the criterion must be satisfied before the process can 
terminate.

[Syntax: DAMPSTEP<=r>] 
          
Specifies that the initial step length value a⁰ for each line search (used by the QUANEW, 
HYQUAN, CONGRA, or NEWRAP technique) cannot be larger than r times the step length value used 
in the former iteration. If the DAMPSTEP option is specified but r is not specified, the default 
is r=2. The DAMPSTEP=r option can prevent the line-search algorithm from repeatedly stepping into
regions where some objective functions are difficult to compute or where they could lead to floating 
point overflows during the computation of objective functions and their derivatives. The DAMPSTEP=r 
option can save time-costly function calls during the line searches of objective functions that 
result in very small steps.

[Syntax: FCONV= | FTOL=r[n]] 
          
Specifies a relative function convergence criterion.

[Syntax: FCONV2= | FTOL2=r[n]] 
          
Specifies another function convergence criterion.

[Syntax:FSIZE=r] 
          
Specifies the FSIZE parameter of the relative function and relative gradient termination 
criteria. The default value is r=0.

[Syntax: GCONV=r | GTOL=r] 
          
Specifies a relative gradient convergence criterion. The default value is r=1E-8. 
The optional integer value n specifies the number of successive iterations for which 
the criterion must be satisfied before the process can terminate.

Specifies the scaling version of the Hessian matrix used in NRRIDG, TRUREG, NEWRAP, or 
DBLDOG optimization.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that no scaling is done.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the Dennis, Gay, and Welsch (1981) scaling update
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies that di is reset in each iteration

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: INHESSIAN[=r]] 
          
Specifies how the initial estimate of the approximate Hessian is defined for the 
quasi-Newton techniques QUANEW and DBLDOG.

[Syntax: INSTEP=r] 
          
Reduces the length of the first trial step during the line search of the first iterations.

[Syntax: LINESEARCH= | LIS=i] 
          
 Specifies the line-search method for the CONGRA, QUANEW, and NEWRAP optimization techniques.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls  for cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is similar to one used by  the Harwell subroutine library.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies a line-search method that needs more function calls than gradient calls for quadratic  and cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is implemented as shown in Fletcher  (1987) and can be modified to an exact line search by using the LSPRECISION= option.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for  cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is implemented as shown in Fletcher  (1987) and can be modified to an exact line search by using the LSPRECISION= option.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for  stepwise extrapolation and cubic interpolation
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies a line-search method that is a modified version of LIS=4.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies golden section line search (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear  approximation.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: Specifies bisection line search (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear  approximation.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Specifies Armijo line-search technique (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for  linear approximation.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: LSPRECISION= | LSP=r] 
          
Specifies the degree of accuracy that should be obtained by the line-search algorithms 
LIS=2 and LIS=3. The default LSPRECISION= values are: 

  o For TECH=QUANEW UPDATE=DBFGS, BFGS: r = 0.4
  o For TECH=QUANEW UPDATE=DDFP, DFP: r = 0.06 
  o For TECH=CONGRA UPDATE=all r = 0.1
  o For TECH=NEWRAP NO UPDATE: r = 0.9

[Syntax: MAXFUNC= | MAXFU=i] 
          
Requires the number of function calls to be no larger than i. The default values are: 

  o For TECH= TRUREG, NRRIDG, NEWRAP: i=125 
  o For TECH= DBLDOG, QUANEW: i=500 
  o For TECH= CONGRA: i=1000
  o For TECH= NMSIMP: i=3000 
  
Note that the optimization can terminate only after completing a full iteration. 
Therefore, the number of function calls that is actually performed can exceed the 
number that is specified by the MAXFUNC= option.

[Syntax: MAXITER= | MAXIT=i[n]] 
          
 Requires the number of iterations to be no larger than i. The default values are: 
 
  o For TECH= TRUREG, NRRIDG, NEWRAP: i=50 
  o For TECH= QUANEW, DBLDOG: i=200 
  o For TECH= CONGRA: i=400
  o For TECH= NMSIMP: i=1000 
  
These default values are also valid when i is specified as a missing value.

[Syntax: MAXSTEP=r[n]] 
          
Specifies an upper bound for the step length of the line-search algorithms during 
the first n iterations.

[Syntax: MAXTIME=r] 
          
Requires the CPU time to be no larger than r. The default value of the MAXTIME= option 
is the largest double floating-point number on your computer. Note that the time specified 
by the MAXTIME= option is checked only once at the end of each iteration. Therefore, the 
actual running time can be much longer than that specified by the MAXTIME= option. The 
actual running time includes the rest of the time needed to finish the iteration and the 
time needed to generate the output of the results.

[Syntax: MINITER= | MINIT=i] 
          
Specifies the minimum number of iterations. The default value is 0. If you request more 
iterations than are actually needed for convergence to a stationary point, the optimization 
algorithms can behave strangely. For example, the effect of rounding errors can prevent the 
algorithm from continuing for the required number of iterations.
Suppresses the output.
[Displays all optional output for optimization.
Displays the optimization history.
Display parameter estimates in each iteration.
Displays the initial values and derivatives (if available).
Restricts the amount of default output.

Restricts the amount of default displayed output to a short form of iteration history and 
notes, warnings, and errors.

[Syntax: RESTART= | REST=i > 0] 
          
Specifies that the QUANEW or CONGRA algorithm is restarted with a steepest descent/ascent 
search direction after, at most, i iterations, i > 0.
Specifies the fileref that contains the information needed for remote monitoring.

[Syntax: TECHNIQUE= | TECH=name] 
          
Specifies the optimization technique.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Chooses one of four different conjugate-gradient optimization algorithms, which can be more  precisely defined with the UPDATE= option and modified with the LINESEARCH= option.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Performs a version of double-dogleg optimization, which uses the gradient to update an approximation  of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Performs a usually stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming Newton-Raphson  optimization technique. The algorithm combines a line-search algorithm with ridging, and it  can be modified with the LINESEARCH= option.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Performs a usually stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming Newton-Raphson  optimization technique. This algorithm does not perform a line search.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: Chooses one of four different quasi-Newton optimization algorithms that can be more precisely  defined with the UPDATE= option and modified with the LINESEARCH= option.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: Performs a usually very stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming trust-region  optimization technique. The algorithm is implemented similar to Gay (1983) and Moré and Sorensen  (1983).
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Does not perform any optimization. This option is similar to METHOD=NONE, but TECH=NONE also  computes and displays residuals and goodness of fit statistics.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies the update method for the quasi-Newton, double-dogleg, or conjugate-gradient 
optimization technique.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Performs the original Broyden, Fletcher, Goldfarb, and Shanno (BFGS) update of the inverse  Hessian matrix.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Performs the dual BFGS update of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian matrix. This is the  default update method.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Performs the dual Davidon, Fletcher, and Powell (DFP) update of the Cholesky factor of  the Hessian matrix.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Performs the original DFP update of the inverse Hessian matrix.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Performs the automatic restart update method of Powell (1977) and Beale (1972).
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Performs a conjugate-descent update of Fletcher (1987).

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: XCONV= | XTOL=r[n]] 
          
Specifies the relative parameter convergence criterion. For all techniques except NMSIMP, 
termination requires a small relative parameter change in subsequent iterations. The default 
value is r=1E-8 for the NMSIMP technique and r=0 otherwise. The optional integer value n 
specifies the number of successive iterations for which the criterion must be satisfied 
before the process can be terminated.

[Syntax: XSIZE=r > 0] 
          
Specifies the XSIZE parameter of the relative parameter termination criterion. The default 
value is r=0.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: OUTPUT <OUT=SAS-data-set> <output-options> ; 

The OUTPUT statement creates a new SAS data set containing all the variables in the input data set and, 
optionally, the estimates of x'β, the expected value of the response variable, and the probability 
that the response variable will take on the current value.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: DISPERSION=name 
          
Names the variable that contains the value of dispersion for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

Syntax: GDELTA=name 
          
Names the variable that contains estimates of g’δ for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

Syntax: LAMBDA=name 
          
Names the variable that contains the estimate of λ for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

Syntax: MODE=name 
          
Names the variable that contains the integral part of μ (mode) for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

Syntax: MU=name 
          
Names the variable that contains the estimate of μ or the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

Syntax: NU=name 
          
Names the variable that contains the estimate of ν for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

[Syntax: OUT=SAS-data-set] 
          
Names the output data set.

[Syntax: PRED=name | MEAN=name] 
          
Names the variable containing the predicted value of the response variable.

[Syntax: PROB=name] 
          
Names the variable containing the probability of the response variable taking the 
current value, Pr(Y=y).

Syntax: PROBCOUNT(value1 <value2…>) 
          
Outputs the probability that the response variable will take particular values.

Syntax: PROBZERO=name 
          
Names the variable that contains the value of ϕ, the probability of the response variable taking on the value of zero as a result of the zero-generating process.

Syntax: VARIANCE=name 
          
Names the variable that contains the estimate of variance.

[Syntax: XBETA=name] 
          
Names the variable containing estimates of x'β.

[Syntax: ZGAMMA=name] 
          
Names the variable containing estimates of z'ϒ.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: PERFORMANCE <performance-options> ;

The PERFORMANCE statement controls the number of threads that are used in the optimization phase.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: NTHREADS=number 
          
Specifies the number of threads to be used during optimization of the model.
Specifies that no threads should be used during optimization of the model.
Specifies that a timing table be included in the output.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: PRIOR parameter-list ~ distribution ;
      
The PRIOR statement is used to specify the prior distribution of the model parameters. 
You must specify a single parameter or a list of parameters, a tilde ~, and then a 
distribution with its parameters. Multiple PRIOR statements are allowed.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: BETA(SHAPE1=a, SHAPE2=b, MIN=m, MAX=M) 
          
Specifies a beta distribution that has the parameters SHAPE1 and SHAPE2 and is defined between MIN and MAX.

Syntax: GAMMA(SHAPE=a, SCALE=b) 
          
Specifies a gamma distribution that has the parameters SHAPE and SCALE.

Syntax: IGAMMA(SHAPE=a, SCALE=b) 
          
Specifies an inverse gamma distribution that has the parameters SHAPE and SCALE.

Syntax: NORMAL(MEAN=μ, VAR=σ^2) 
          
Specifies a normal distribution that has the parameters MEAN and VAR.

Syntax: T(LOCATION=µ, DF=v) 
          
Specifies a noncentral t distribution that has DF degrees of freedom and a location parameter equal to LOCATION.

Syntax: UNIFORM(MIN=m, MAX=M) 
          
Specifies a uniform distribution that is defined between MIN and MAX.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: RESTRICT restriction1 <, restriction2 …>;
      
The RESTRICT statement imposes linear restrictions on the parameter estimates. You can specify 
any number of RESTRICT statements. 

Each restriction is written either as a single linear equation or as a comma-separated list of two 
or more linear equations. A restriction equation consists of an expression, followed by an equality 
operator (=) or an inequality operator (<, >, <=, >=), followed by a second expression: 

  expression operator expression
  
The operator can be =, <, >, <=, or >=.

Syntax: SCORE <OUT=SAS-data-set> <output-options>;

The SCORE statement enables you to compute predicted values and other statistics for a SAS data set.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: DISPERSION=name 
          
Names the variable that contains the value of dispersion for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

Syntax: GDELTA=name 
          
Names the variable that contains estimates of g’δ for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

Syntax: LAMBDA=name 
          
Names the variable that contains the estimate of λ for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

Syntax: MODE=name 
          
Names the variable that contains the integral part of μ (mode) for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

Syntax: MU=name 
          
Names the variable that contains the estimate of μ or the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

Syntax: NU=name 
          
Names the variable that contains the estimate of ν for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

[Syntax: OUT=SAS-data-set] 
          
Names the output data set.

[Syntax: PRED=name | MEAN=name] 
          
Names the variable containing the predicted value of the response variable.

[Syntax: PROB=name] 
          
Names the variable containing the probability of the response variable taking the 
current value, Pr(Y=y).

Syntax: PROBCOUNT(value1 <value2…>) 
          
Outputs the probability that the response variable will take particular values.

Syntax: PROBZERO=name 
          
Names the variable that contains the value of ϕ, the probability of the response variable taking on the value of zero as a result of the zero-generating process.

Syntax: VARIANCE=name 
          
Names the variable that contains the estimate of variance.

[Syntax: XBETA=name] 
          
Names the variable containing estimates of x'β.

[Syntax: ZGAMMA=name] 
          
Names the variable containing estimates of z'ϒ.
Displays all applicable contents
Displays the "Class Level Information" table. This table is produced by the COUNTREG procedure by default if the model contains effects that depend on classification variables.
Produces the correlation matrix of the parameter estimates.
shows all open SAS data sets.
Produces the covariance matrix of the parameter estimates.
Displays information about the effects in the model.
Displays the fit statistics from the item store.
Displays the parameter estimates table from the item store.
Displays the SAS program that generates the item store, provided that this was stored at store generation time. The program does not include comments, titles, or some other global statements.

Syntax: SELECT=INFO<(selection-options)> | SELECTVAR=INFO<(selection-options)> 
          
Requests that the variable selection method be based on an information criterion.

Syntax: SELECT=INFO<(selection-options)> | SELECTVAR=INFO<(selection-options)> 
          
Requests that the variable selection method be based on an information criterion.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: SPATIALID variable;

For a spatial lag of X model, the SPATIALID statement specifies a variable that identifies a spatial 
unit for each observation in the two data sets that are provided by the DATA= and WMAT= options in the 
PROC COUNTREG statement.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: SELECT=INFO<(selection-options)> | SELECTVAR=INFO<(selection-options)> 
          
Requests that the variable selection method be based on an information criterion.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: STORE <OUT=>item-store-name;

The STORE statement saves the contents of the analysis to an item store in a binary format that cannot be modified. 
You can restore the stored information by specifying the RESTORE= option in the PROC COUNTREG statement and use it 
in postprocessing analysis.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: OUT=item-store-name
          
Specifies the item store name where the contents of the analysis are saved.
Requests Wald, Lagrange multiplier, and likelihood ratio tests.
Requests the Lagrange multiplier test.
Requests the likelihood ratio test.
Requests the Wald test.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: WEIGHT variable </ option> ; 
      
The WEIGHT statement specifies a variable to supply weighting values to use for 
each observation in estimating parameters. The log likelihood for each observation 
is multiplied by the corresponding weight variable value. 

If the weight of an observation is nonpositive, that observation is not used in 
the estimation.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Does not normalize the weights. By default, the weights are normalized so that 
they add up to the actual sample size.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: ZEROMODEL dependent variable ~ zero-inflated regressors / options ; 

The ZEROMODEL statement is required if either ZIP or ZINB is specified in the DIST= option in the
MODEL statement. If ZIP or ZINB is specified, then the ZEROMODEL statement must follow immediately
after the MODEL statement. The dependent variable in the ZEROMODEL statement must be the same as 
the dependent variable in the MODEL statement.

The zero-inflated (ZI) regressors appear in the equation that determines the probability of a zero count.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: LINK=LOGISTIC | NORMAL 
          
Specifies the distribution function used to compute probability of zeros.

Syntax: OFFSET=variable
          
Specifies a variable in the input data set to be used as a zero-inflated (ZI) offset variable. 

The ZI offset variable is included as a term, with coefficient restricted to 1, in the equation 
that determines the probability (φi) of a zero count. The ZI offset variable cannot be the response 
variable, the offset variable (if any), or one of the explanatory variables. The name of the data 
set variable used as the ZI offset variable is displayed in the “Model Fit Summary” output, where 
it is labeled as "Inf_offset".
